summary: A humorous take on the unwavering loyalty and often contradictory enthusiasm for programming languages, centered around Jackson Monaghan's erratic presentation of C#. The video presents a satirical narrative of tech evangelism, highlighting the absurdity and contradictions in the fervor surrounding programming technologies.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing glasses and a blue checkered shirt is seated in front of a computer monitor displaying code. He is actively engaged in a conversation, using expressive hand gestures to emphasize his points. The background features a wall with a geometric design and a curtain, creating a casual and home-like atmosphere. The man's facial expressions and body language suggest he is explaining or discussing a topic with enthusiasm and clarity. The setting appears to be a personal workspace, with a desk and various items like a coffee mug and a book visible in the background. The video captures the man's dynamic interaction, highlighting his animated communication style and the informal yet focused environment.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker talking about "one of the most popular and loved languages on this planet, according to Microsoft".  Then music begins, which appears to be electronic in style, playing loudly and rhythmically with an energetic tone. The speaker returns, uttering, "I'm ready", then names "Microsoft Java," before correcting it to, "C Sharp." The speaker continues describing C Sharp, "struggling to keep track whether C Sharp is cross-platform or not," and explaining it's always been cross-platform, noting "it's 2022, Microsoft is different now, object-oriented, and declarative, and functional."  He continues talking about dot net framework being more than C Sharp and creating your own language, adding, "but nothing beats C Sharp," and discusses "tweaks and changes and changes on top of changes."

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing glasses and a blue shirt is seated in a room with a computer monitor displaying code in the background. He is actively engaged in a conversation, using hand gestures to emphasize his points. The room features a modern design with a wall adorned with circular patterns and a curtain on the left side. A white mug with the Microsoft logo is placed on the desk next to the monitor, which also shows a bright glare. The man appears to be explaining or discussing something related to the code on the screen, as indicated by his expressive hand movements and focused facial expressions. The setting suggests a casual yet professional atmosphere, possibly a home office or a creative workspace.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a deep male voice stating, "That was decades ago," which is immediately followed by another male voice, with a slightly more enthusiastic tone, correcting "one decade ago." The second speaker continues, stating that "C# is different now," and goes on to say that "C# has always been cross platform" since 2016, and "always been open source" since 2014, questioning why one would let the community contribute to something "so perfect and evolving," with a more rhetorical tone. Finally, the speaker emphasizes "C#" followed by "Microsoft."

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing glasses and a blue shirt is seated in front of a computer monitor displaying code. He is actively engaged in a conversation, using expressive hand gestures to emphasize his points. The background features a wall adorned with circular patterns in shades of brown and beige, and a curtain on the left side. A white mug with the word 'Microsoft' is visible on the desk, along with a blue box labeled 'IN DEPTH' and a digital clock showing '10:01'. The man's facial expressions and body language suggest he is explaining or discussing a topic with enthusiasm and clarity. The setting appears to be a home office or a casual workspace, with a warm and inviting atmosphere. The video captures the man's dynamic interaction with the audience, highlighting his communication skills and the engaging nature of his presentation.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a male speaker enthusiastically discussing C Sharp as a suite of tools, naming "Visual Studio", "corporate", and ".net". He questions, in a pondering tone, how people write code without Visual Studio. He then mentions that "C Sharp and .Net are separable," and goes on to quickly list different variations of .Net, like ".net core", ".net framework", ".net micro framework", ".net compact framework" and others. The speaker sounds out of breath as he reaches ".Net Five". The recording ends with a sigh.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing glasses and a blue checkered shirt is seated in a room with a beige curtain and a wall adorned with circular patterns. He is animatedly gesturing with his hands while speaking, occasionally pointing towards a computer monitor displaying a bright screen. The man's expressions and gestures suggest he is engaged in a lively conversation or presentation. The room's decor includes a desk with a computer setup, and a sign on the desk reads "CH 7.0," indicating a channel or frequency setting. The atmosphere is casual and focused, with the man's dynamic movements and expressions adding energy to the scene.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip opens with a male speaker musing on the C# programming language, contrasting it with other languages and mentioning features such as the "nullability operator." He lists several related technologies including "Skype," ".Net", and "common language runtime." The speaker emphasizes the popularity of C#, countering an objection about its popularity from a comment, perhaps from "2015." Finally, he signs off stating he will be in the studio. The speaker speaks in a calm, conversational tone.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing glasses and a blue shirt is seated in a room with a computer monitor displaying code. He is actively engaged in a conversation, using hand gestures to emphasize his points. The background features a wall with circular patterns and a curtain, creating a cozy atmosphere. The man appears to be explaining something with enthusiasm, as indicated by his expressive hand movements and facial expressions. The computer monitor shows a bright screen with lines of code, suggesting that the discussion might be related to programming or technology. events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker passionately promoting the benefits of C#, mentioning its "second mover advantage," a "great community of experts," and "expensive consultants." He then highlights ASP.NET's popularity as a web application framework, mentioning ASP.NET Core, before continuing to describe the popularity of C# as making one "marketable in the marketplace." He concludes with the statement, "it's not just marketing."

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing glasses and a blue checkered shirt is seated in front of a computer monitor displaying code. He is actively gesturing with his hands, indicating that he is explaining or discussing something. The background features a wall with circular patterns in shades of brown and beige, and a curtain is visible to the left. The man appears to be engaged in a conversation or presentation, as he uses expressive hand movements to emphasize his points. The setting suggests a casual, home office environment, with a focus on the man's interaction with the audience.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker enthusiastically emphasizing the financial benefits of learning C#, stating "Look at all the opportunities for C# devs out there". He continues, expressing the sentiment that C# should be learned for financial gain rather than pleasure, stating "You don't learn C# to have fun". He further elaborates on this, suggesting a cycle of using earnings from C# to then have fun learning more C# to earn even more. The male speaker then states "Let's uncover a great myth here" and clarifies that C# isn't only for game development.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing glasses and a blue checkered shirt is seated in front of a computer monitor displaying code. The setting suggests a home office or a personal workspace.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker talking about Unity and being "not sponsored by" Microsoft, his tone is informative. A loud crashing sound interrupts the speech. The speaker resumes, noting that "the survey isn't biased by vendor lock-in" and discussing C# and VR. A cough follows. He mentions "HoloLens" and features of C#, such as "implicit types, anonymous functions." His voice is slightly elevated and energetic when talking about new features.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing glasses and a blue checkered shirt is seated in front of a computer monitor displaying code. The man's facial expressions and body language suggest he is explaining or discussing a topic with enthusiasm and clarity. events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a man providing tech jargon, naming a series of programming language terms like "unary plus, link, C# mascot Andy, .net mascot, .net bot, malware mascot, .net botnet". He then shifts in tone, making a skeptical remark about the necessity of features, stating "they're not just adding random stuff no one asks for; I asked for it". A lighthearted complaint follows: "no one asked me. C++ is a waste of time." He emphasizes that C++ is "faster than anything that is not compiled, strongly typed." He continues with a mix of technical comparisons and opinion, discussing stability and security, mentioning "Java and C# are totally different things" and noting the differences in their virtual machines and frameworks. A dismissive tone returns with "no competitor has this." The man concludes with a product-oriented focus stating, "Let's talk about Azure. Azure pipeline"

events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features one male speaker discussing similarities between Microsoft's C# and Java, mentioning "mutual stealing," "copying," and "inspiration," and explaining dynamic types. His tone is analytical and slightly critical. The speaker notes changes made in the switch statement.

events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a male speaker passionately discussing technical concepts with enthusiasm, referencing topics like "garbage collector" and "pointers," and frequently interjecting with rhetorical questions, such as "But why?" and "Why would anyone?" There's a brief interlude where he mentions "implicit using," "having a function," and "having a runtime." Then, the speaker apologizes, stating that the "boss was calling." The clip concludes with the speaker abruptly saying "Shh" before ending.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing glasses and a blue shirt is seated in a room with a computer monitor in front of him. The computer monitor displays a bright screen, and there is a white mug on the desk. events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a synthesized tone, followed by a male speaker's voice discussing C# programming language features and aspects in a clear, informational tone. He uses various phrases like "innovation", "are you bored?", "default skeleton is not the same", and touches upon topics like "just in time", "anonymous functions", and its similarities with Java and JavaScript. Occasionally he voices concerns using a tone tinged with humor. The speech is clear and professional. A subtle hum of background ambiance exists in the clip. The speaker continues with more commentary on C#, adding suspense, before suddenly exclaiming about seeing a C developer, questioning their presence in a C# environment, highlighting the specialized nature of their environment. As he continues his talk, he expresses enthusiasm and humor.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing glasses and a blue checkered shirt is seated in a room with a computer setup. He is actively engaged in a conversation, using hand gestures to emphasize his points. The background features a wall with circular patterns and a curtain, creating a cozy atmosphere. On the desk, there is a monitor displaying a bright screen, a keyboard, and a white mug with the Microsoft logo. Additionally, a blue box labeled 'C# 7.0' is visible, indicating the programming language being discussed. The man appears to be explaining or demonstrating something related to the computer, as he occasionally looks at the screen and interacts with the keyboard. The overall setting suggests an informal yet focused environment, likely a home office or a personal workspace.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker humorously comparing C# and .NET versions to being "on steroids," and then jokes about "fake teeth" and "too much syntax sugar." He introduces something to "buy you in", which he clarifies means to "convince, unbiased." There is a sound of something breaking, after which the speaker comments on the chair not being of "Microsoft quality," and reintroduces the idea of something to "buy you in." The clip concludes with a sound of breaking something, presumably the chair. The speaker's tone is jovial and lighthearted, shifting to a slightly annoyed tone when the chair breaks.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing glasses and a blue checkered shirt is seated in a room with a modern aesthetic, featuring a wall adorned with circular patterns in shades of brown and beige. He is engaged in a conversation or presentation, gesturing with his hands to emphasize his points. In front of him, a computer monitor displays lines of code, suggesting a technical or programming-related discussion. On the desk, there is a white mug with the Microsoft logo, indicating a possible affiliation or interest in the company. Additionally, a book titled "C# 7.0" is visible, reinforcing the theme of programming. The man's expressions and gestures convey enthusiasm and engagement, as he appears to be explaining or discussing a topic with passion. The overall atmosphere is professional and focused, with the man's attire and the setting contributing to a sense of expertise and dedication to the subject matter.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker stating that "hardly anybody will claim" Java or C# are "revolutionary programming languages" that have "changed the way we do things" with a fairly neutral tone. His tone turns more emphatic when he says, "Nobody ever. C# is the greatest." Next, the same speaker makes an aside, "Oh, we had that already." The speaker continues, saying "the LTS is three years," and explains that "people cannot explain to the clients that they have to modernize their software every three years," but declares confidently, "I can. I can." The speaker then uses an expression that sounds like "symbol soup." Another speaker interjects, stating, "Just chiming in to say that I really like the new nullability operator, and I really like to use it." Finally, the first speaker concludes with a light-hearted tone, "Well, that wasn't that hard. Couple of lies here and there, huh?"

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing glasses and a blue checkered shirt is seated in front of a computer monitor displaying code. He is actively engaged in a conversation, using hand gestures to emphasize his points. The background features a wall with a geometric design and a curtain, creating a professional yet casual atmosphere. On the desk, there is a book titled "CH 7.0" and a white mug with the Microsoft logo, indicating a possible connection to technology or software development. The man's facial expressions and body language suggest he is explaining or discussing a topic with enthusiasm and clarity. The setting appears to be an office or a home workspace, with the focus on the man and his interaction with the audience.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a male speaker discussing Windows Forms and related development frameworks like WebForms, MVC, JTK Sharp, Silverlight, HTML JS, WPF, and UWP, with a tone that suggests frustration or disbelief. He mentions a cyclical return to Windows Forms and references cross-platform options like "Xamarin Forms, or how it's called."

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a man wearing glasses and a blue shirt is seated in a room with a computer setup behind him. He is actively gesturing with his hands while speaking, indicating he is explaining or discussing something. The computer screen displays code, and there is a book titled "C# 7.0" on the desk, suggesting a focus on programming or software development. The room has a modern aesthetic with a wall featuring circular patterns and a curtain on the left side. The man's expressions and hand movements convey enthusiasm and engagement in his topic. The video maintains a consistent setting and atmosphere throughout, with the man continuing his discussion and the computer screen remaining visible in the background.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker mentioning ".NET Maui" and "Mono's incomplete implementation of WinForms," followed by a dismissive "whatever they're doing." He transitions to a more emphatic tone, stating, "Everybody must download and install the huge .NET runtime," seeing it as "a form of commitment to .NET." Continuing, he mentions that "CIL byte code is easy to reverse engineer" and says they are "basically giving you the code open source for free. How nice of us." He asserts that ".NET Framework is gonna be supported for years to come. It will never die." The speaker notes that "there are still people in remote parts of the world that still haven't heard of .NET Core, .NET 5, Windows Edge, or Firefox." He then observes that C# "is not the only one with cluttered syntax," reminding that "there is still JavaScript." He ends the clip by posing a question: "Why Java developers wear glasses?" followed by a somewhat mocking explanation: "Well if they can't see out of their eyes..."

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man wearing glasses and a blue checkered shirt, seated in front of a computer monitor displaying lines of code. He appears to be engaged in a discussion or presentation, gesturing towards the screen and pointing at specific lines of code. The background includes a wall with circular patterns and a curtain, creating a casual and focused atmosphere. The man's expressions and gestures suggest he is explaining or analyzing the code, possibly discussing its functionality or structure. The camera captures close-up shots of the code on the screen, highlighting the details and syntax of the programming language being used. The man's interaction with the code and his attentive demeanor indicate a deep engagement with the technical content. The video maintains a consistent setting, emphasizing the man's interaction with the code and his role as an instructor or presenter.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a male voice suggesting the use of a console to read lines, followed by an instruction to cut the recording. There is a sound of someone getting ready, then an "all right" from the same male voice, followed by "I'm so ready". This is followed by a second male voice saying, "come in, see this" and a few one-to-three-word computer code phrases said by that person, like "byte me," "interrupt," "return to sender," "volatile personality," "unsafe at any speed," and "go to". The same male says a short comment about some code being his, then says "check this" a few times. We hear that packages are being restored for a solution, and this might take a while, followed by a statement about restoring packages and then a need to crunch this. We then hear "Targeting .net 6 and Visual Studio. See, that's what I mean."  Then the statement is made that they don't send crash reports, some analyzer information, and then something about build with 24 errors and a need to take a break. This is followed by someone asking if that's a "CTF again", someone saying they really like the new "nullable operator" and, then saying, "the one of..." something is a "one in a million," followed by a whoop. There is then a question about trying something else, and another whoop. There is mention of using something not supported in C sharp and then sending code in the crash reports.
